Antonia, de 60 años es madre soltera que tubo que criar a su hija sola, vive junto a ella que ahora tiene 23 años y es abuela de un menor, tiene una casa propia que pudo comprar con bastante esfuerzo.El trabajo de Antonia consiste en la venta de bebidas heladas, este trabajo lo realiza en su casa, lleva aproximadamente dos años y esta actividad lo hace sola pues su hija trabaja en otro lugar y le apoya a pagar los gastos de la casa. 
Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que tiene tiempo disponible para realizar otras actividades, lo que no le gusta es que a veces tiene que quedarse hasta un poco pasada la noche por que alguno de sus clientes vienen tarde a comprar, espera poder mas adelante implementar su negocio en otro rubro.Este es el sexto préstamo entre Antonia y la institución MFP, esta conforme con el grupo que es socia ya que todos se muestran muy responsables y puntuales en sus pagos, esta muy agradecida con la institución ya que siente que confían en ella y le dan la oportunidad de sentirse útil.Con el monto solicitado 2000 soles, comprará mas bebidas para tener en stock, además de comenzar con la venta de hielo y las bebidas de diferentes medidas.
texts.en:
Antonio, age 60, is a single mother who had to raise her daughter alone.  Her daughter is now 23, and Antionia is the grandmother of a minor child.  She has her own house, which she was able to buy with a great deal of effort.

Antonia’s work consists of selling cold drinks.  She does this work at home.  She has been doing this for approximately two years.  She does this work alone because her daughter works at another place and helps her to pay the household expenses.

What she likes about her work is that she has free time to do other activities.  What she does not like is that she sometimes has to stay late at night because one of her customers comes to shop late.

Later she hopes to be able to set up her business in another another field.

This is Antonia’s sixth loan with the MFP institution.  This is in accordance with the group that she is a member of.  All of them are very responsible and punctual with their payments.  She is very grateful to the institution because she feels that they have faith in her and give her the opportunity to feel useful.

She will use the 2,000 soles that she has requested to buy drinks to have in stock.  Aslo, she will start selling ice and different sizes of drinks.

loans.use: to buy drinks to have in stock.  Aslo, she will start selling ice and different sizes of drinks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy rice, beans and groundnuts to resell.

loans.name: Alnie

texts.en:
Alnie is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase spare parts for motorcycle maintenance.

Alnie has been in this business for eight years. Alnie earns more income from services (manicure & pedicure).

Alnie has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for motorcycle maintenance

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is 38 years old and married with five children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Helen is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Helen has been raising pigs for 12 years and earns additional income from buying and selling charcoal and food vending.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business and send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Mirasol

texts.en:
Mirasol is 31 years old and married with two children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Mirasol is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to purchase feed & vitamins for her pigs.

Mirasol has been raising pigs for three years and earns additional income from buying and selling rice grains & motorcycle transport.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase feed & vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Yosia

texts.en:
Yosia is a married father of six children age 13 to 2 years old, living in his own house in Hioma, Uganda.

The responsibility to look after the family solely rests on him and his dream is to educate his children. 

He has been operating a bar business for one year and the only challenge he faces is lack of adequate capital to meet the demands of the customer base.

His dream is to move into a more spacious place that can accommodate 100 clients. 

Yosia needs the loan to buy beers and sodas for resale.

loans.use: To buy beers and sodas for resale.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en: Hellen is 44 years old. She is a widow with four children. Three of her children are in school. She has a business selling charcoal in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She has been in this business for five years. She earns additional income from selling bread. Hellen requested this loan from BRAC South Sudan to enable her to purchase more charcoal for sale.

loans.use: to purchase or order more charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma is 44 years old and married with three children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,500 loan through NWTF to purchase more items to sell in her sari-sari store.

Vilma has borrowed and paid five loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for five years and also earns income from raising pigs.

Vilma aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Minda Luz

texts.en:
Minda Luz is 53 years old and married. She lives in the town of Banga, South Cotabato, with her family.

Minda Luz and her husband are both farmers. They primarily grow rice crops to sell. 

Minda Luz also sells chorizo to the people in her community. Minda Luz does her best to support her family. 

She applied for a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and more chorizo to sell. She hopes to earn more and improve their house.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and more chorizo to sell.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna is 43 years old and married with three children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell.

Myrna has borrowed and repaid 14 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for six years and also earns income from food vending.

Myrna aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock to sell.

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine  lives in Uganda. She is married and has six children, all of whom are in school. Justine lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, rent and school fees.   

Justine has a business of selling used shoes. She has been in this business for seven years, and she works seven days out of every week.  

Justine sells her products at the market by means of retail.  

Justine has requested a loan of 40,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of used shoes.   

The main business challenges for Justine include thieves and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start importing shoes and also to be a wholesaler.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used shoes.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is a 26-year-old hardworking man living in a rented house in Karuguuza, Uganda. 

For four years he has been running a grocery shop and from it he has been able to pay school fees for his children. 

He faces a challenge of inflation but hopes to expand his business to a wholesale status. 

Julius needs a loan to buy soap, sugar and cooking oil for resale.

loans.use: To buy sugar, soap and cooking oil for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Shernalyn

texts.en:
Shernalyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a "tricycle" transport business in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 23,000 through NWTF to renew her mechanics tools and equipment for her "tricycle" transport business.

Shernalyn has been in this business for 10 years. She earns more income from bakery and food vending.

Shernalyn has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to renew her mechanics tools and equipment.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is aged 25 and does mixed farming in her hometown area of Kisii, South Rift Kenya for close to ten years. Her farm produces maize and cucumbers which she sell locally. She gets supplementary income from her wholesale business which deals with maize.

Alice made a request of 25,000 KES loan from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She still has plans to buy more dairy cows. She believes all these are possible with loan and will also be able to educate her children and provide basic requirements.

Alice says Juhudi is doing a great job in helping farmers but laments about high costs of pesticides and poor markets for the produce, especially milk.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To pay fees for her children.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 28 years old and married with 4 children aged 11-1, living in a rented house in Hioma. For 4 years she has been hawking clothes and from this business she has been able to pay school fees for her children. She started with 200,000 shillings but now she has an inventory worth 2,500,000 shillings. Her challenge is that the business is seasonal and her dream is to own a boutique.

Elizabeth needs the loan to buy clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy clothes for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy tools & pay for gasoline for the service.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is 41 years old and married. She has two children aged 12 and 6. Nancy and her family live in Banga, South Cotabato.

Nancy is a farmer. She has been growing rice and corn crops for 10 years. Nancy sells her harvest at the market and earns about 6500 PHP per month. Nancy works hard to improve her business and provide for the increasing needs in her household.

Nancy has requested a loan to purchase one sack of seeds, two sacks of fertilizers and one quart of herbicide. She hopes to acquire the farming equipment she needs. She also hopes for her children to be able to finish college and have bright futures.

loans.use: to purchase one sack of seeds, two sacks of fertilizers, and one quart of herbicide.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy cassava flour for sale.

loans.name: Sabrina

texts.es: Sabrina, de 32 años, es una mujer alegre y trabajadora, vive en casa de su padre junto a su hermano, abuelita, cuñada, tres sobrinos, sus dos hijos y su esposo.El trabajo de Sabrina consiste en salir a ofrecer sus productos, ella vende ropa de segunda en los caseríos y comunidades nativas cerca de la ciudad, además ella invierte parte de su dinero en la compra de sierras y discos de aserraderos, este trabajo lo hace ya varios años, y la venta de ropa desde hace un año.Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que puede disponer de tiempo para sus dos actividades, además que siempre hay ingresos, en estos momentos esta bien con su negocio, prefiere mantenerlo así y espera poder consolidarse en lo que hace.Este es el séptimo préstamo entre Sabrina y la institución MFP, se siente bien en el grupo que conforma pues dice que todos son muy responsables, además refiere estar súper contenta con trabajar con la institución pues le dan la oportunidad de crecer en su economía.Con el monto solicitado 3000 soles, comprará ropa de segunda, además de discos de aserradero para su posterior venta.
texts.en:
Sabrina, age 32, is a happy and hard-working woman.  She lives in her father’s house with her brother, grandmother, sister-in-law, her brother’s three children, her two children, and her husband.

Sabrina’s work consists of going to sell her products.  She sells second hand clothes in the villages and indigenous communities that are close to the city.  She also invests part of her money by purchasing saws and saw blades.  She has been doing this for several years.  She has been selling clothes for one year.

What she likes about her work is being able to have time for both business activities.  Also, there is always income.  She is now doing well with her business, and she prefers to keep it that way.  She hopes to be able to consolidate what she does.

This is Sabrina’s seventh loan with the MFP institution.  She feel good being in her group, and she says that they are all very responsible.  Also, she reports that she is super happy working with the institution.  They give her the opportunity to grow financially.  She will use the requested 3,000 soles to buy second hand clothes and discs for saws that she will later sell.

loans.use: to buy second hand clothes and discs for saws that she will later sell.

loans.name: Saima

texts.en: Saima is 49 years old and married with two children who are in school. She has a business selling food in her hotel (restaurant) in Kator Branch in South Sudan.  She has been running this business for four years. Saima requested this loan from BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business. Her aim is to buy a car in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more items like plates and serving spoons to operate a hotel (restaurant)

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie is 44 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with five children. 

Tessie has a shop that sells used clothing like t-shirts and blouses. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy stocks of used clothing.

Tessie has been a member of HSPFI since 2000. In the future, Tessie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy stocks of used clothing

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
43-year-old Rosalie earns a living through farming. She is married and has two children aged 18 and 20. Her husband works as a farmer and driver.

Rosalie and her husband till land in Banga, South Cotabato. They grow rice and corn crops to sell. 

Rosalie applied for a loan to purchase three sacks of fertilizers, two sacks of rice seeds and two quarts of insecticides. This loan will help Rosalie and her husband continue their farming business.

loans.use: to purchase three sacks of fertilizers, two sacks of rice seeds and two quarts of insecticides

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy used clothes to sell

loans.name: Chona

texts.en:
This is Chona, 30, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Jose Ramy, an Overseas Filipino Worker. She manages her household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Chona operates a rug-making business. Her products are small rugs and larger doormats. She makes door mats out of excess textile cloth she bought from the factory. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, they are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. She directly sells her products to her neighbors and the local community, as well as to suppliers. She earns a minimum of 200 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales daily.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php10,000 loan. She will utilize the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Chona hopes to grow her business to be able to help in the construction of their house in the coming years. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and make microloan repayments.

loans.use: to pay for additional stock of raw materials she needs in her business

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 46 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 3 children.

Teresita has a flower shop that sells a variety of flowers like orchids and baby's breath. She has had this business for 5 years. She requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to buy fertilizers for flowers to sell.

Teresita has been a member of HSPFI since 2002. In the future, Teresita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for flowers

loans.name: Xavier

texts.en:
Xavier is 65 years old and married with 11 children aged between 42 and 20 living in his own permanent house in Hoima, Uganda. For 4 years, he has been a tea out-grower (contract farmer). He started as a casual laborer at the factory and later saved money to buy land on which he now grows tea.

His major challenge is the high cost of inputs such as manure, but he hopes to expand his tea plantation in the next five years. Xavier wants a loan to buy inputs such as fertilizers for his garden.

loans.use: to buy inputs (fertilizers, etc.) for his garden

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia is 41 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 2 children.

Lucia has a poultry farm that sells chickens by the kilogram. She has had this business for 11 years. She requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to buy animal feed for chickens she will sell.

Lucia has been a member of HSPFI since 2006. In the future, Lucia hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy animal feed for chickens

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 46 years old and lives in Taboc Norte, Oroquieta City. She is married with 2 children.

To earn a living, Elizabeth has a fish vending business. She earns about 5,000 PHP each month doing this type of work. Elizabeth has a requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase more fish to sell.

Elizabeth has been a member of PMPC for 1 year.  In the future, Elizabeth would like to have big capital from her business to help her family.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a motorcycle for transport business

loans.name: Welliam

texts.en:
Welliam is 41 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with 3 children. 

Welliam has a shop that sells cocoa fruits, coffee fruits and bananas. He has had this business for 10 years. He requested a loan for PHP 4,000 to buy bananas and cocoa fruits for sale.

Welliam is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Welliam hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy bananas and cocoa fruits for sale

loans.name: Mkolemba Group

texts.en:
Richard is in his early 30s and is married with one small daughter.  He has been running a hardware shop for three years now. He works from 9 a.m to 9 p.m daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.
 
This will be his first Motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He wants to use the loan for buying more electrical spares for his hardware shop. A Motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania given in the middle of the main loan that motivates borrowers with good credit ratings who pay back their  loans smoothly to receive half amount of the existing loan before their original loan term has ended. 

Richard will share this loan with his loan group, "Mkolemba", which has a total of 5 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. His dream is to one day be able to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more electrical spares

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Edilberto

texts.en:
Edilberto is 32 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is single. 

Edilberto has a shop that sells cocoa fruits and coconuts. He has had this business for 5 years. He requested a loan for PHP 4,000 to buy cocoa fruits and coconuts for sale.

Edilberto is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Edilberto hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy cocoa fruits & coconuts for sale

loans.name: Shiela

texts.en:
Shiela works hard to support her family. She is married and has a business buying and selling dried fish  in the Philippines. Shiela requested a PHP 29,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more dried fish to sell.

Shiela has been in this business for four years now and also earns additional income from selling purified drinking water and charcoal.

In the future, Shiela would like to save enough money so she can continue to send her children to college and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda is 46 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 11 children. 

Rosalinda has a flower shop that sells different kinds of flowers. She has had this business for 5 years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy fertilizers for the flowers for sale.

Rosalinda has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Rosalinda  hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for flowers for sale

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Feliciana is 56 years old and married with three children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a variety store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 19,500 loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell in her store.

Feliciana has borrowed and repaid eight loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the variety store for eight years and also earns income from tailoring.

Feliciana aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell in her store.

loans.name: Cecile

texts.en:
As a married mother of four children, Cecile works hard to support her family. She has a machine shop business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from food vending. Cecile is borrowing PHP 17,500 through NWTF to purchase tools and equipment for her machine shop business.

Cecile has been sustaining her business activities through her past 11 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase tools and equipment.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is 41 years old and married. She has 3 children aged 17, 16 and 13.

Rosemarie has been a farmer for 18 years. She and her husband till land in Banga, South Cotabato. They primarily grow rice crops to sell. Rosemarie requested a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes for their business to be stable and would enable them to sustain their children's education.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Ruthy

texts.en:
Ruthy works hard to support her family. She is married and has a grinder business in the Philippines.

Ruthy requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional equipment and for the maintenance of the grinder. She has been in this business for five years now.

In the future, Ruthy would like to save enough to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy additional equipment and pay for maintenance of grinder.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is 27 years old and has two children. She is married and her two children are in school.

Evangeline is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. Evangeline requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Evangeline has been raising pigs for two years now and has borrowed five times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Evangeline would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Leo

texts.en:
Leo is 32 years old and married. He has 2 school-aged children living with him in Jimenez, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. 

Leo is peddling fresh fish variants in the local community to make a living. He has been doing this job for 4 years already. The business has been able to provide approximately PHP 2,500 a month for the family.

Earlier this year, Leo joined GDMPC to have an access to financial services. This is the first loan ever taken by him from the cooperative. His loan application is worth PHP 10,000 which will be used to purchase fresh fish supplies and in return sell to the local community.

Leo hopes to obtain enough revolving funds for the business and acquire enough resources to vend. In so doing, he can gain more income and get the chance to build up a small fish stall operated in its own place in the mini-market lane.

loans.use: To obtain fresh fish supplies and sell to the local community.

loans.name: Ma. Fe

texts.en:
Ma. Fe is 52 years old and married with four children. With one child in school, Ma. Fe works very hard to proviD. for the family.

Ma. Fe runs a variety store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 19,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell. She has been in this business for six years and sells a variety of items such as snack foods, noodles, and school supplies. 

In the future Ma. Fe would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more beans and peas to resale.

loans.name: Lyneth

texts.en:
Lyneth is 33 years old and married with four children. With all four children in school, Lyneth works very hard to provide for them.

Lyneth runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell. She has been in this business for 2 years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, soft drinks, and other groceries. 

In the future Lyneth would like to build and expand her business to support the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Rostere

texts.en:
Rostere is 39 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is widowed with 6 children. 

Rostere has a shop that sells canned goods, biscuits and snacks. She has had this business for 5 years. She requested a loan for PHP 7,000 to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Rostere has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Rostere hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is 32 years old, She is married with two school-aged children. The family is residing in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. 

Virginia is a retailer of various ready-made or RTW products. These include baby wear, blankets, pillowcases,and more. Every month she earns PHP 8,000.

Earlier this year, Virginia joined GDMPC. She has applied for a loan of PHP 15,000 to purchase additional RTW's to sell such as blankets, clothes, accessories, etc. She expects to gain more revenue from the additional products to sell and to improve the general living condition of the family.

loans.use: To purchase additional RTW's to sell such as blankets, clothes, accessories, etc.

loans.name: Marita

texts.en:
Marita is a 48-year-old married woman. She settled to earn her living in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines together with her two adult children. Over the past three years, Marita was able to put up a rice and corn retail store that absolutely met the market primary demands. Until now, the business is still doing well and is giving enough cash inflow to cover the family's day-to-day expenditures. Every end of the month, Marita approximately receives a total of PHP 23,100 from the store  operations.

Marita joined GDMPC earlier this year to have an easy access to financial services. Her first loan application from the cooperative worth PHP 15,000 has been approved. The money taken is intended to obtain additional rice and corn variants to sell. With the acquisition of in-demand basic commodities, Marita expects an increase in sales so as to expand her business and improve the general living conditions of the family.

loans.use: To obtain additional rice and corn variants to sell.

loans.name: Merry Grace

texts.en:
Merry Grace is 25 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with one child. 

Merry Grace has a shop that sells green & yellow bananas & coconuts. She has had this business for two years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy bananas & coconuts to sell.

Merry Grace has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Merry Grace hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy bananas & coconuts for sale.

loans.name: Cate

texts.en:
Cate  lives in Uganda.  She is married and has four children, three of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (her grandson). 

Cate has a food stall.  She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Cate sells her products from home, by means of retail. Cate has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more baskets of fish and bunches of bananas. 

The main business challenges for   Cate include thieves and debtors.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to see her business grow big and also to sell wholesale only. 

Cate lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include paying utility bills, rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of fish and bunches of bananas

loans.name: Ruben

texts.en:
Ruben is a 54-year-old married man with one child. His son is 21 years old.

Ruben is a farmer. He tills a plot of land in the town of Banga, South Cotabato. Ruben grows rice and corn crops to sell. He also raises pigs in his backyard. Ruben sells his pigs at the market.

Ruben is requesting a loan to purchase five sacks of fertilizers, one quart of herbicide and four sacks of rice seeds. He hopes to earn better and be able to renovate their house.

loans.use: to purchase five sacks of fertilizers, one quart of herbicide, and four sacks of rice seeds.

loans.name: Jovita

texts.en:
Jovita is a single lady who settled for a living in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She started operating a retail store at home when she was 31. 

Now, Jovita is 37 years old. This means that she is now in her sixth year of business operations and is really doing very well. She, approximately, earns a monthly income of PHP 10,000, which comes from the store inflows alone.

Jovita joined GDMPC, earlier this year. She is applying for a loan of PHP 15,000 from the organization. This will be the first  loan transaction done by Jovita. She will buy small-sized dividers to organize her display of stock from the loaned amount. A business expansion is a long-time plan of Jovita's because she depends solely on her store. From the probable revenue generated, Jovita will allocate a portion to purchase a fridge.

loans.use: To buy small-sized dividers to organize her display of inventory.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma is 36 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has 6 children.  

Alma has a shop that sells green & yellow bananas & coconut for copras. She has had this business for 6 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy bananas & coconut.

Alma has been a member of HSPFI since 2008. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: buy bananas & coconut

loans.name: Jean Aida

texts.en:
Jean Aida, a 55 year-old-woman, is married but has no children to care for. She is a resident of Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. Farming is her main source of income. She often works under the heat of the sun and even under heavy rain just to cope with the time, to finish what needs to be done in a day.  Her life situation looks like this most often, but she managed to withstand it for 5 years until the present time. Every month, Jean Aida gets a total of PHP 10,000 from her work.

Earlier this year, Jean Aida became a GDMPC member. She is applying a loan of PHP 5,000 to pay for land preparation costs. She hopes to start planting the crops allotted for the area soon, and expects a large harvest made possible by this loan. Jean Aida plans to purchase the required fertilizers for quick growth and pesticides to protect the plants from harmful pests.

loans.use: pay to prepare her land for farming

loans.name: Wilfred

texts.en:
Wilfred is a resident of and a farmer in the Kisii area in South Rift Kenya. He lives with his family of two children, and practices farming with the help of one farmhand.  He produces a variety of vegetables and beet roots, which he sells to the local market.

Wilfred has made a loan request for 25,000 KES through Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow.  He says the dairy cow's income will help him improve his family's living standards, educate his youngest child, and further expand his farm in the future.

Wilfred observes that the lack of organised markets is a challenge to farmers in the area.

loans.use: buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is from Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She is 36 years old and is married. Gardening is Susan's main source of income. She has been planting various root crops, shrubs, and the like to earn a living and cover everyday needs. Her innate interest in doing such activity made her stay in the business for 5 years until the present. She normally makes a monthly income of PHP 6,000 from it.

Susan joined GDMPC earlier this year. She is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 from the organization to purchase seeds and seedlings to raise, such as eggplants, cucumber, radish, etc. Vegetables are being promoted in every household as healthy and good.  Susan hopes to earn more income from this investment and cultivate adjacent lands to extend her product distribution to the market place.

loans.use: buy seeds and seedlings

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is a 54-year-old woman living in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store at home to cater to neighborhood's daily consumption. She has been running her store for 3 years.  This business operation normally provides her a total of PHP 3,000 a month.

Marilou has been a GDMPC member since this year. She has applied for a loan worth PHP 5,000 from the cooperative. She will use the money to buy additional grocery stocks to sell.  She means to attain her goal of improving and expanding her business, that is why she is exerting more effort. With the probable gain in revenue, she hopes to buy a new fridge for drinks .

loans.use: buy more grocery stocks to sell

loans.name: Servando

texts.en:
Servando is 46 years old and married. He has a 9-year-old child. Servando and his family live in the town of Banga, South Cotabato.

Servando is a farmer. He owns the land that he tills to grow rice, corn and vegetables. Servando sells his harvest to rice traders. He plans to use his loan to purchase 4 sacks of rice seeds, 5 sacks of fertilizers, and 1 liter of pesticides. Servando hopes to achieve an abundant quality harvest.

loans.use: purchase seeds, fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Basit

texts.en:
Basit is a 37-year-old man living in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. He has 2 school-aged children -  both are attending school. For the past five years, he has been selling snack items around schools and nearby communities. All are deliciously prepared and very affordable. The monthly income received by Basit depends solely on this activity.  He frequently gets a total of PHP 10,700 a month.

Basit joined GDMPC earlier this year to have easy access to financial services. This first loan application taken by him from the organization is worth PHP 5,000.  He intends to obtain more snack items to sell such as fish crackers, toasted breads, chicharons, etc. using the amount borrowed. 

Basit is expecting a greater return from this investment. He hopes to sustain his livelihood and own a food stall in a school canteen close to his residence.  By doing so, he can earn more income for his family and gradually improve their general living condition.

loans.use: buy snack items to resell

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.en:
The man whose picture appears above is Ricardo. He is 31 years old and is married. Living with him in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines, are 4 school-aged children. Ricardo and his spouse are much happier having the children. He was able to send all his children to school through his gardening activity. 

Ricardo plants a variety of crops and sells them to multiple buyers when they are grown.  For 11 years, he never ceased and has learned to love the work he does for a living. Every month, he receives a total of PHP 11,440 from gardening.

Earlier this year, Ricardo joined GDMPC to have easy access to financial services. His approved loan application from the cooperative is worth PHP 5,000. He will use it to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Some of these are eggplants, root crops, shrubs and many more.  With the help of the new investment taken from the cooperative, Ricardo hopes to bring in the right and productive crops. He plans to gradually expand the cultivated area and plant more to increase his usual income generated each month.

loans.use: buy seeds and seedlings

loans.name: Marvelina

texts.en:
Marvelina is 43 years old and is married to a local farmer. She has two school-aged children. Marvelina is a determined and responsible mother. Aside from nursing their child, she also keeps herself busy in maintaining her farming business to produce better yield. With her husband, she plants and harvests rice.  Marvelina earned PHP 25,000 from the last crop season in May.  The profits earned were used to sustain her business and pay school fees and bills.

Marvelina is requesting a loan amount of P14,000 to pay for farm inputs such as seeds, fertilizers and insecticides used in farming. She wants to regain some profit since the last crop was a loss for her due to a typhoon affecting most of their farm. She hopes this loan will be a great help for her in providing sustenance for her farming business for the next crop harvest in November.

In the future, Marvelina would like to keep making better crops to obtain the income necessary to support all the needs of the family. She also would like to earn additional income for house repair.

loans.use: buy farm inputs

loans.name: Ethelyn

texts.en:
Ethelyn is a 22-year-old woman living in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She is married and has one infant child to care for. For the past three years, she has been running a retail store at home to earn a living. At a very young age, Ethelyn gradually learned about business dealings. From her business, she normally earns a monthly income of PHP 3,700. She properly apportions this total to pay her day-to-day expenses.

Earlier this year, Ethelyn joined GDMPC to have easy access to financial services. She is applying a loan worth PHP 5,000 from the cooperative. She will spend the money to purchase daily-use merchandise to sell such as laundry soap, canned goods, toothpaste, etc. Ethelyn expects to generate more sales and additional income, made possible by this loan. She is looking forward to an expansion of her store, thereby improving the general living condition of her family.

loans.use: buy merchandise to resell

loans.name: Julmar

texts.en:
Julmar is 26 years old. He is married with one school-aged child to attend to. The family settled to live in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. He buys various snack items and sells them for a profit. He is selling these commodities along a crowded road. Where there are many people passing by, there is a bigger chance of selling more or of eventually selling out of stock for the day. For 2 years, Julmar has been enjoying his job. His regular earnings from this activity have reached a total of PHP 5,200.
Earlier this year, he joined GDMPC to have easy access to financial services. He is now requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 from the organization to purchase several snack items to sell such as popcorn, crackers, and many others. By having these supplies to sell, Julmar hopes to increase his income and set aside a small amount to have adequate on-hand financing for the business. He plans to own a two-wheeled cart to ease selling by making his way through nearby communities.

loans.use: To purchase several snack items to sell such as popcorn, crackers, and many others.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita is a 58-year-old-woman. She is married and living in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She has four grown children to care for. 

She sells sweet banana cue (a deep-fried banana snack) in the local community to make a living. Every day, she wakes up early in the morning and prepares everything to start up business operations. She's invested so much time and effort to keep the business. Though not the primary source of income, Rosita still gets a monthly income of 4,200 Philippines pesos (PHP) from the activity.

In 2010, she officially became a member of GDMPC. This is her third loan application from the cooperative and it is amounting to PHP 5,000. The money is for buying materials necessary for banana cue selling. She makes the food by herself and sells it around local community. By having started the business, Rosita hopes to bring in adequate supplies of materials in subsequent operations to keep it going and offer more food items to vend to surpass the normal flow of earnings.

loans.use: To buy materials necessary to sell banana cue (a deep-fried banana snack).

loans.name: Twaib

texts.en:
Twaib is a 34 year-old married man with four children and he owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. The responsibility to look after the family rests on him and his desire is to educate his children to attain degrees as a minimum qualification.

He has had a retail shop for four years and he got his initial capital from farming. His hardship is high commodity prices and his vision is to have a big retail shop and to educate his children.Twaib needs the loan in order to buy sugar and soap to sell.

loans.use: to buy sugar and soap to sell.

loans.name: Richel

texts.en:
Richel is 30 years-old. She is married with two school-aged dependents. The family is settled in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She is cultivating land to earn a living. She grows various crops and sells them to community members and at the town market for a profit. She has already spent the last three years of her life tilling fertile soil. Every month, she gets a total of PHP 3,000 from the work.

Richel is now a member of Kiva partner GDMPC. She can now access financial services offered by the cooperative to some extent. In this third loan application for PHP 10,000, she can compensate for land preparation cost and start planting another set of crops for additional production in the future. Richel plans to plant as much as she can, to generate enough for the family and buy more lots to increase farm production.

loans.use: to pay for land preparation costs.

loans.name: Louela

texts.en:
Louela is 50 years old and has four children. She is a widow and has one child who is still in school.

Louela is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. Louela requested a PHP 28,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. She has been raising pigs for 30 years now and has borrowed 20 times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

Louela would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn is 46 years-old and is separated from her husband. She has five grown children living with her in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. Twenty years ago, she started running a retail store to make a living. Until the present, the business has continued to grow and is successfully operated by the family. The store offers mostly daily use commodities such as noodles, spices, rice, shampoo, bath and laundry soap and many others. She earns PHP 4,200 a month for the store operations.

In 2009, she began her transactions with Kiva partner GDMPC. For the second time around, Merlyn is applying for a loan of PHP 5,000 from the organization to obtain a few sacks of rice to sell in the community. She has to sustain the livelihood. In the future, Merlyn hopes to expand the business  and improve the general living condiiton of her family.

loans.use: to buy sacks of rice to sell in the community.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is a widowed woman living in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She is 56 years-old with 2 grown dependents. 

She is a farmer. She has been digging, plowing and planting for the last two years. Last harvest, she earned enough to compensate for all the time and efforts invested to make it fruitful. Despite fortuitous events that hampered the plants growth, Erlinda managed to stand still and think positively. The farm regularly gives monthly inflows of PHP 4,500.

In 2010, Erlinda joined Kiva partner GDMPC in order to haveeasy access on financial services. She has borrowed twice from the cooperative making the latest application the third one. The current loan is in the amount of PHP 7,000 which will be used to purchase farm fertilizers to haste growth. By putting in enough fertilizers for growth, Erlinda expects a good return on investment. She intends to lay aside a portion of her earnings and purchase a lot for gardening activity.

loans.use: to purchase farm fertilizers to hasten growth.

loans.name: Atyrkul's Group

texts.en:
Atyrkul, 44, is the leader of this group. She is married and lives in the town of Balykchi. Atyrkul and her husband have different spheres of work. He is a truck driver and she is a chemistry and biology teacher in a local high school. However, the free time of both of them is devoted to taking care of cattle. It’s been five years since the couple started widening their household and building appropriate conditions for livestock.  The monthly profit from breeding and reselling of cattle is 4 200 soms. Atrykul’s big wish is to support financially her son’s ambitions for studying abroad. Therefore, she applied for a loan in order to pay her son’s college tuition. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to pay for her son's college tuition.

loans.name: Jolly

texts.en:
This is Jolly, 29, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Julius, an electrician, with whom she has two children. Jolly and her husband manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Jolly operates a door mat business. Her products are small rugs and larger doormats. She makes door mats out of excess textile cloth she bought from the factory. As rugs are a major part of Filipino house keeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding down the highway. She is also into the direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products of popular brands. She directly sells her products to her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000. She will use the loan to buy more raw materials like fabric and thread. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Jolly hopes to grow her business in the coming years, and for her family she hopes that they will remain strong even in times of trial. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials and products she needs for her door mat business.

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva lives in Uganda. She is single and has 3 children, three of whom are in school. She has a business operating a retail shop. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Eva sells her products in a shop. Eva has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from Kiva's partner, MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt and boxes of soap .  

The main business challenges for Eva include transportation and debtors. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to see it grow big so that she can sell on wholesale only and also to buy a plot of land. Eva lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include paying utility bills, rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, and boxes of soap

loans.name: Gracelinda

texts.en:
Gracelinda works hard to support her family. She is married and has a business buying and selling coconuts in the Philippines.

Gracelinda requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more coconuts to sell. She has been in this business for 10 years.

Gracelinda would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more coconuts to sell.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en: Henry is a married man. He runs a vehicle repair business in Mombasa. He has been in this business for ten years now. He says that the business is profitable and the major challenges he faces are financial constraints. He is requesting this loan of KES 30,000 to buy spare auto parts to grow his business and meet the demands of his customers. He describes himself as a friendly person.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for his vehicle repair business

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
Conchita, 67, is a widow with 4 adult-aged children. She is from Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She owns and operates a retail store at home to make a living. She has been running this business for 21 years now. Conchita has gone through many challenges brought on by the business and is now used to it. The store operations generate revenues of PHP 9,200 a month.

In 2008, Conchita joined Kiva's partner, GDMPC, to gain access to financial services. She is a frequent borrower and a good payer of the cooperative. She is currently requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 from the cooperative to purchase daily use commodities to sell. She will lay aside a portion of the revenue generated by this investment to buy a small-sized stock divider to organize the merchandise for sale.

loans.use: To purchase daily use commodities to sell.

loans.name: Lucewin

texts.en:
Lucewin is married with five children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Lucewin is 41 years old and has four children who are in school.

Lucewin has a sari-sari  (variety) store business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 15,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase more items to sell.

Lucewin has been in this business for 10 years. In the future, Lucewin would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell.

loans.name: Lucresia

texts.en:
Lucresia is 44 years old and married with four children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Lucresia is borrowing PHP 21,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Lucresia has been raising pigs  for 10 years and also earns  additional income from her vegetable vending business.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she can continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Cirila

texts.en:
Cirila is 57 years old and married. She is blessed with 7 grown children who have helped her with cultivating the land. The family lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. Farming is the family's main source of income, as it is for most of their community. She has been irrigating, plowing and planting on farm fields for 2 years. Green surroundings create a healthy and lovely environment around the farm fields. Cirila normally receives PHP 5,280 from her farm production.

Cirila joined Kiva's partner, GDMPC, earlier this year to have easier access to financial services. She is applying for a loan of PHP 7,000 from the organization to purchase fertilizers and pay for irrigation costs. The rice variant has just been planted and hopefully will produce the expected amount of produce. Cirila is planning to buy a farm sprayer soon to facilitate fertilizer application more easily.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pay for irrigation costs.

loans.name: Aliya's Group

texts.en: Women entrepreneurs make a significant contribution in the development of the business sphere, both on a local and country level. Since the opening of the large retail and wholesale market Dordoy, thousands of entrepreneurs rushed for new opportunities to make money. Aliya, 27, is a leader of this group. For more than six years, she has been one of the 20,000 entrepreneurs who were employed in Dordoy. She sold clothing apparel and shoes. This experience has helped her obtain knowledge and skills about trade and communication with various types of clients. Recently, Aliya moved to her hometown Balykchi, where she bought a spot in a newly built market. The total start-up capital resulted in 10,000 soms. Aliya is divorced and has a 7-year-old daughter. Currently, she needs to buy necessary electronics for her home. For this purpose, she requests a loan from Kiva lenders. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase home appliances.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 60 years old and married with one child. She works very hard to provide for her family.

Evelyn runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 22,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. She has been in this business for 15 years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, soap, milk, and other groceries. 

In the future Evelyn would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy items to sell in her little store.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a retail banana business in the Philippines.   She is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to buy additional fruits and vegetables to sell.  Emma has been in this business for 12 years.   She earns additional income from raising livestock.  Emma has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF.  She dreams of saving enough money, so she can send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy additional fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora is a married lady. She runs a restaurant in which she sells soup and meat in Mombasa. She has been running it for two years now. She says that this business is profitable. The major challenge she has is that there are other people in the area running the same kind of business as hers, so customers are not loyal as they are spoiled for choice. 

She is using her loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more meat to grow her business and meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to open a big hotel in the future. She describes herself as a very hardworking and honest lady.

loans.use: to buy more meat.

loans.name: Romelie

texts.en:
Romelie is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a food vending business in the Philippines.   Romelie has been in this business for 4 years.  

She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy additional stock of ingredients for her business.  She earns additional income from a motorcycle transport business.  Romelie has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF.  She dreams of saving enough money so she can send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy additional stock of ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more crates of soda

loans.name: Jarkynai's Group

texts.en:
Jarkynai, 19, is the leader of this group. She a young and ambitious entrepreneur who resides in the coal mining town of Tashkomur.  She is a mother of a young toddler, and to make a living she breeds, raises, and sells cattle.  When she gave birth to her daughter, she was given her first animal to raise, which her husband helps to take care of. Since then, two years have passed, and now she owns several heads of livestock and earns a monthly income of 7,000 soms. The purpose of this loan is to purchase more livestock. Jarkynai has a medical education and her dream is to earn enough money to open her own pharmacy. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en: Lilian is a fifty-four-year-old married woman with six children who owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been operating a clothing boutique for twenty-five years.  She started by selling second-hand clothes and now sells new clothes. One hardship she faces in business is its seasonal nature. Her dream to open a second clothing shop somewhere in town.  Lilian plans to use the proceeds from this loan to buy more clothes to resell.

loans.use: to buy clothes for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase 50 bags of charcoal for her business,

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion works hard to support her family.  Salvacion is married and has a meat vending business in the Philippines.  She has been in this business for 7 years.

Salvacion requested a PHP 19,500 loan through NWTF to buy additional meat for sale.  In future, Salvacion would like to save enough to provide financial stability for her family.

loans.use: To buy additional meat for sale

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a 30-year-old married woman with two children. She lives in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda. Her dream is to build her own house.

She owns a boutique, and has been in business for five years. She started by first working as an attendant, got capital and started her own business. Her main challenge has been the high prices of commodities, but she believes with hard work, she will be successful. Rose needs the loan to buy blankets, carpets and bed covers to sell.

loans.use: To buy blankets, carpets and bed covers to sell.

loans.name: Saturnina

texts.en:
Saturnina is 63 years old and married with 6 children.  She works hard to provide for her family.  She runs a sari sari store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 26,000 loan through NWTF, to buy more inventory like sugar, groceries, etc. for sale in her sari sari store.

Saturnina has borrowed and paid 7 loans from NWTF before this one. She has been running the sari sari store for 30 years, and also earns an income from her vegetable vending business.

Saturnina aspires to build and expand her business, to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To buy more inventory to sell in her sari-sari store

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace lives in Uganda. She is single and has three children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of an additional family member (mother).

Grace has a business of selling used bras and half slips. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works seven days out of every week. Grace sells her products at the market, by means of retail.  

Grace has requested from MCDT SACCO a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings, which she will use to buy more bales of used bras and half slips. The main business challenges for Grace include transportation and the rainy season. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to see her business grow big so that she sells on a wholesale basis only, and also to start importing bras herself. 

Grace lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include paying for electricity, rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bales of bras and half slips.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy used bags and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Carmela

texts.en:
Carmela is 65 years old, married with 5 children, and works very hard to provide for them.  She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines.  Carmela has been in this business for 10 years and sells a variety of items such as sardines, oil, spices, eggs, etc.. 


She has requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF, to buy additional items like sugar, groceries, etc. for sale in her sari-sari store.  In the future, Carmela would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy additional items for sale in her store

loans.name: Jonadel

texts.en:
Jonadel is 36 years old and married with 4 children.  She earns her living by raising pigs in the Philippines.  Jonadel has been raising pigs for 2 years and also earns an additional income from her motorcycle transport business.

Jonadel is borrowing PHP 21,500 through NWTF, to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.  She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream, of saving enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more goods for her shop

loans.name: Foutuma

texts.en: Foutuma is 32 years old and married with one child. She has a business selling food in her restaurant. She has been in this business for two years. She requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business and she will use the extra income to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase items to operate her restaurant

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy sugar, maize flour, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Zaillia

texts.en: Zaillia is 39 years old and married with five children. All of her children are in school. She has a business selling bread in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She earns additional income from her Dobbi (washing clothes). She took this loan from BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business. The extra income from this loan she will use to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to purchase more bread to sell

loans.name: Help We Sef Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you members of the “Help We Sef” group. These are small-scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek a loan of SLL 3,500,000 SLL for the entire group in order to invest in their respective businesses. 

Fatmata (pictured on the right) is the leader of this group. Fatmata is 45 years old, married with six children, two of whom are attending primary and secondary schools respectively. Fatmata has been selling market food for the past 30 years now. With her share of this loan, she is going to buy beans, onions, tomatoes, Maggi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), etc. to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: to buy beans, onions, tomatoes, Maggi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), etc. to add to her business inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy bread.

loans.name: Leh Den Help We Group

texts.en:
The leader of the “Leh Den Help We” group, Fatmata is 38, married and has one child in secondary school. Her husband is a businessman. She was born in the city of Makeni but she now lives in Waterloo in western Sierra Leone.

For sixteen years now, Fatmata has been selling clothes. With the help of this loan, she is going to buy clothes in bulk to boost her business.

In this photo are members of her group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Waterloo where “Shine on Sierra Leone” partnered with SMT to start a branch. This is these entrepreneurs’ first loan from SMT. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more money and consequently improve on their standards of living.

loans.use: to buy clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Tadeo

texts.en:
Tadeo is a 27-year-old married man with two children. They live in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. The responsibility to look after the family rests on him, and his desire is to educate his children up to university level.

For five years Tadeo has operated his retail shop. His main challenge has always been inadequate stock to meet the increasing demands of customers due to limited capital to invest. Tadeo needs a loan of 1,800,000 UGX to buy sugar, rice, soap, cooking oil and paraffin to sell.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice, soap, cooking oil and paraffin.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more chairs and tables.

loans.name: Shayirbubu's Group

texts.en:
Shayirbubu, 46, is the leader of this group. She is married and has three children, the youngest of whom is financially dependent on her. When she and her husband got married, they received some poultry, which they grew at home and used for the family’s consumption. Soon she turned it into a small profit-making business, selling poultry and eggs to the very first of her customers.

Now Shayirbubu breeds cattle as well as poultry and receives 6,500 KGS a month. This is quite enough to furnish the house and buy other conveniences.

With a loan of 80,000 KGS Shayirbubu plans to broaden and diversify her livestock breeding further. She will use the loan to buy additional livestock.

loans.use: to buy additional livestock.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more fresh produce to sell.

loans.name: Seluwa

texts.en: Seluwa is 38 years old. She is a widow with five children. Two of the children are in school. She has a business selling beans in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She has been in this business for five years. Seluwa requested this loan from BRAC South Sudan to purchase more beans to sell with the hopes of expanding her business. She will use the profit from her business to pay for her children to go to school and to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more beans to sell

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is married with two children aged thirteen and ten years. She is a farmer who lives in Kisii, South Rift, Kenya. She has been farming for three years growing carrots, onions and bananas which she takes to the local market. She also runs a retail shop within the local market to supplement her farming income. The lack of organized markets for the farmers and the effect of pests on animals and production in general are her major problems.

Gladys has requested a loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says the income derived from this cow will enable her to get a better education for her children by taking them to better schools.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Sabenty Group

texts.en:
Amie is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Amie was born in Kambia town, 45 years ago. She is married to an imam and the couple has 4 children who are attending secondary schools. 

For 15 years now, Amie has been selling cooked food and palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil). This is the first loan that Amie and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. Amie will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to expand her business. She will buy 50 gallons of palm-oil and 5 bags of rice.

loans.use: to buy 50 gallons of palm-oil and 5 bags of rice.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is a thirty nine year old married man with three children and he rents a house in Kasese, Uganda. He is solely charged with the responsibility of looking after the family and his desire is to educate his children to attain degrees as minimum qualifications. 

Julius has been operating a shop that has home use items and soft drinks for three years and he got his initial capital from farming. His hardships are bad debtors and high transport costs. Never the less, his vision is to diversify and to set up a hotel while also having an educated family. Julius needs the loan facility to buy a fridge so as to preserve the drinks in his shop.

loans.use: to buy a fridge.

loans.name: Aishabubu's Group

texts.en:
Aishabubu, 52, is treasurer of this group. She is divorced and lives in a town of Tokmok. She has two grown sons who live on their own. This entrepreneur has been selling fruits and vegetables in a local food market for the past two years. Her initial capital was 5,000 soms. Aishabubu is happy that her investment paid off, because she now earns 6,000 soms a month. This requested loan will be invested in the purchase of a new house, which Aishabubu desperately needs. Aishabubu hopes to always have fresh wholesale fruits and to be in demand. She thanks all Kiva lenders for the financial assistance. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Foo-Foo Group

texts.en:
Salamatu is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Salamatu was born in Masimra village 36 years ago. She is married to a driver and the couple has 4 children who attend primary and secondary school. Salamatu sells palm-oil and foo-foo (food made out of cassava roots). Salamatu has been doing this business for 10 years now. 

With the help of this loan, Salamatu and her group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and, consequently, improve on their living conditions. Salamatu will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to buy palm-oil and foo-foo in large quantities to add to her business.

loans.use: to buy palm-oil and foo-foo in large quantity to add to her business.

loans.name: Vicent

texts.en: Vicent is a thirty one year old married man with two children and he rents a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the retail shop business for three years. He started his business with 500,000 shillings and now has 3,000,000 shillings as his working capital. His hardship is lack of enough capital to supply the customers. His vision is buying a motorcycle, finishing his house and educating his children. Vicent intends to use the loan to buy flasks, omo (soap) and sodas to sell.

loans.use: to buy flasks, omo and sodas.

loans.name: Shake Hand Group

texts.en:
Meet with members of the “Shake Hand” group from Waterloo, a small town in western Sierra Leone where “Shine On Sierra Leone” partnered with SMT to start a branch. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, also a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of 500,000.00 SLL for each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. 

Fatmata is the leader of this group. This 45-year-old is married to a trader and they have 6 children, 4 of whom are attending primary and secondary schools.  Fatmata sells cooked rice. She has been doing this business for 10 years now.  With her share of this loan, she will buy cooking ingredients – rice, palm-oil, fish, tomatoes, onions, etc., in large quantities, in order to cook a larger quantities of rice to sell.

loans.use: to buy cooking ingredients – rice, palm-oil, fish, tomatoes, onions, etc., in large quantities, to cook a larger quantity of rice for sale.

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en: Dorothy is 27 year old woman, married, who has 2 children, aged four years old and one year old. She runs a general store in which she sells various items to the local people in Mombasa. She has been in this business and says that the business is profitable. The major challenges she has are financial constraints. She is using her loan of KES 20,000 to buy more general items to expand her business and meet the demands of her customers. In the future she hopes to diversify to a green grocery business. She describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: to purchase rice, sugar, cooking oil, flour, etc,

loans.name: Jamila's Group

texts.en:
Jamila, 50, is a leader of this group. She is married, has two grown children and resides in a small town of Karabalta. While her son owns 20 hectares of land and cultivates vegetables, Jamila takes care of livestock and has a small dairy business. Twenty one years of this business has generated 7,800 soms a month. The land and livestock was inherited from Jamila’s father, to whom she is grateful, because he showed the importance of land for a farmer. Throughout these years Jamila has improved her family’s financial state. Her family’s assets now include good electrical appliances. Jamila would like to request a loan from lenders in order to buy a refrigerator for home. 

           --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a fridge.

loans.name: Kision

texts.en: Kision is a thirty one year old married man with four children. He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been operating a retail shop for three years. He started with capital of 300,000 shillings from coffee savings and now he has capital of 3,000,000. His hardship is high inflation rates and his vision is having another retail shop. He also wishes to educate his children. Kision needs the credit facility to buy sugar, salt and drinks to sell.

loans.use: to buy sugar, soap, salt and drinks to sell.

loans.name: United Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “United” group from Waterloo, a small town near Freetown where “Shine on Sierra Leone” partnered with SMT to start a branch.
