They are small businessmen who have come to SMT, also a partner of Kiva.org, in order to seek a loan of 500,000 SLL for each in the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit and consequently improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Aruna. Aruna was born in the northern township of Magburaka, about 26 years ago. He is married and has 2 children. His wife is a nurse and his children are still not of school-going age. Aruna has been running a telephone/mobile phone booth for the past 5 years now. He has requested for this loan in order to buy top-up cards for all four mobile networks for resale, to buy chargers, etc.

loans.use: to buy top-up cards for all four mobile networks for resale, to buy chargers, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more beans, coffee, and maize to offer for sale

loans.name: Alhamdulilai Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you members of the “Alhamdulilai” group. These are small-scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT and Kiva lenders to seek a loan of 700,000.00 SLL to invest in their businesses. 

Musa is the leader of this group. Musa is 60 years old and married with 5 children – 2 in primary school and 3 in secondary school. Musa sells groundnuts and has been a businessman for more than 30 years. With the help of this loan, Musa will invest in his business by buying about 30 bags of groundnuts to sell.

loans.use: to buy 30 bags of groundnuts to sell.

loans.name: Kono Group

texts.en:
Aminata is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Born 32 years ago in the city of Koidu, Aminata is married and has 2 children.  For 3 years, Aminata has been selling cooking oil, sugar, gari (food made out of cassava roots), margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), onions, pepper, groundnuts, palm oil, rice, etc. Aminata will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to expand her business by buying these items in bulk to sell. 

This is the first loan that Aminata and her group members have requested from SMT and Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to buy cooking oil, sugar, gari, margi, onions, pepper, groundnuts, palm-oil, rice, etc. in bulk.

loans.name: Marisa

texts.en:
This is Marisa, age 31, a resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Nepomuceno, a driver. Together with her husband and children, she manages her household while operating the business. She works hard to continually provide income for her family's everyday expenses.

Marisa operates a variety store, where she sells groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood in small quantities. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a small amount of cooking oil, or an egg. Marisa makes a profit by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located next to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php1000 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a Php19,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Marisa hopes to bring her whole family closer to God. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Yovencia

texts.en:
Yovencia is a farmer in Kisii, South Rift, Kenya where she resides with her family of 6 children, 4 of whom are still in school. Her farm produces maize, bananas, nappier grass and poultry, all of which are sold at the local market. She has been farming for 10 years and employs 3 farmhands.

Yovencia has made a loan request of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. In this way, she will be able to educate her children and feed them well. She is focusing on adding more cows once she repays the loan.

Yovencia appreciates Juhudi Kilimo's services and notes pests and diseases are the challenges in farming.

loans.use: to pay for the purchase and insurance of a dairy cow.

loans.name: Fast Moving Group

texts.en:
Isatu is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Isatu was born in one of the several villages in Sanda. She is 35 years old. Isatu is a widow with 2 children who attend secondary school. For 10 years, Isatu has been selling cooked rice with sauce. 

This is not the first loan that Isatu and her group members have received from SMT and Kiva lenders. Previous loans have created significant impact in the lives of these borrowers. 

However, with the help of this loan, they will be able to further expand their respective businesses, make more sales and further improve their living conditions. Isatu is going to use her share of the loan to buy rice, palm-oil, groundnuts, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), etc. in order to cook a larger quantity of rice and sauce to sell.

loans.use: to buy supplies in order to cook a larger quantity of rice and sauce to sell.

loans.name: Nedia

texts.en:
Nedia is 25 years old and married with eight children. Three of her children are in school. She has a business selling tea in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She has been in this business for three years.

Nedia requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase items like a kettle and glasses needed to sell tea. She will use the extra income for paying school fees.

loans.use: to purchase items for selling tea.

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
This is Jennifer, 33, a resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Lino, a security guard. She, together with her husband, manages the own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Jennifer operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages, piecemeal, to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Jennifer earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 250 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Jennifer hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she hopes to draw her family to God. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Amida

texts.en:
Amida is 30 years old and married with three children, all of whom are in school. She has a business selling bread and beans in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She has been in this business for three years. 

Amida requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business. She will use the extra income to pay for her children to go to school.

loans.use: to purchase more breads and beans to sell.

loans.name: Cherryl

texts.en:
This is Cherryl, 30, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Santy, an overseas Filipino worker, and is the mother to their children. She manages her own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Cherryl operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5-Philippines-pesos worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Cherryl earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 750 Philippines pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP18,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Cherryl dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: God Bless Ii Group

texts.en:
Kadiatu is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Kadiatu was born in the village of Yoni in northern Sierra Leone about 39 years ago. She is married to a police officer, and the couple has three children who are attending primary and secondary schools. Kadiatu sells pepper and palm oil and has been doing this business for many years now. 

With the help of this loan, Kadiatu and her group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently, improve their living conditions. Kadiatu will use her share of the loan (1,500,000 Sierra Leone leones) to buy large quantities of pepper and palm oil to add to her business.

loans.use: to buy large quantities of pepper and palm oil to add to her business.

loans.name: Alimamy's Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of a primary school in Allen Town, near Freetown. This school was established in 2004/2005 academic year. The school is staffed with 17 teachers and has an enrollment of over 600 pupils. 

Alimamy is the leader of this group of teachers. Born in Freetown, the 33 year old is married to a secretary and the couple has 1 child. Alimamy has requested for a loan of 1,000,000.00 SLL from SMT/Kiva lenders in order to invest it in a business. He will use it to buy rice, palm-oil, etc. in large quantity for resale.  

This will be the first loan that teachers of this school are requesting from SMT/Kiva lenders. This loan will certainly be of immense help to these teachers. Since salaries are usually small in Sierra Leone; especially so for people in the teaching profession, they could not use such salaries to buy or do anything great. But with a loan, they can now buy or do something big and then repay over a period of time. Some of them will use it to begin or continue building a house; others to pay either for themselves pursue further studies or pay for their children’s education. Some will use it to invest in businesses in order to complement their monthly salaries. And still, others will use theirs to buy pieces of furniture.

loans.use: to buy rice, palm-oil, etc. in large quantity for resale

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
This is Mary Jane, 39, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite City, the Philippines. She is married to Tyron, a messenger, and is the mother to their child. Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating her business, working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Mary Jane operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a small convenience store that sells groceries, toiletries, and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Mary Jane earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them by the piece. Aside from the store she has a food stall, where one can buy home-cooked meals. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 933 every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan of PHP 16,000. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. A portion of the loan will be used to buy quantities of products like meat, rice, vegetables, condiments, and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Mary Jane dreams of being able to give her child a good and high-quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet every week. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine, 45, is a resident of Bacoor, Cavite City in the Philippines. She is married to Larry, a laborer, and is the mother of their children. Together with her husband and children, she manages the household.

In addition to her household chores, Josephine operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which sells groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a five PHP’s-worth of cooking oil, or an egg.

Josephine buys her inventory at wholesale prices and then sells it by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 800 PHP in sales every day. She works hard to continually provide income for her family’s everyday expenses.

Josephine is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan to use to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages so as to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income from doing so. By expanding her income, Josephine soon hopes to have her own house and lot in a nice location.

Josephine faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members who are organized into groups of fifteen to thirty community partners and meet on a weekly basis. There the group studies the Word of God, builds social capital, and repays microfinance loans. Along with others Josephine shares stories of her work and draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God.

loans.use: to pay for the groceries and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Kuljan's Group

texts.en:
Kuljan is the leader of this group. She is 55 and married to a security guard. Together with her husband she has raised five sons, three of whom work in the family’s furniture store while the other two sons work in construction.

A few years ago the family was engaged in selling auto parts. With the profits gained, Kuljan opened a workshop where she and her sons now produce furniture. She also breeds cattle for the additional income it brings.

At the moment Kuljan is applying for a 70,000 KGS loan because she needs additional funds to buy more cattle for breeding. In the near future she plans to start repairs on the house.

loans.use: to buy more cattle for breeding.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 43 years old and married with five children. Four of her children are in school. She has a business selling charcoal in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She has been in this business for five years. 

Elizabeth requested this loan from BRAC South Sudan to order more charcoal to sell with the hopes of expanding her business. She will use the extra income for building a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase or order for more charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Eremina

texts.en:
Eremina is 24 years old and married with three children. Two of her children are in school. She has a business selling charcoal in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She has been in this business for four years.

Eremina requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to enable her to purchase or order charcoal to sell with the hopes of expanding her business. She will use the profit for building and buying a plot in future.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan is 36 years old and married with four children who are all in school. She has a business selling clothes in Kator branch in South Sudan. She has been in this business for three years.

Juan requested this loan from BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business.

loans.use: to purchase clothes for her customers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a welder for his business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase soap, cream, rice, oil, etc.

loans.name: Amos

texts.en:
Amos is fifty years old, married and lives in Kakata, Liberia. He has three children ages fifteen to twenty-nine; one lives at home and attends school while the other two are working and live away from home.

For the past ten years Amos and his wife have operated a mini-restaurant in their community. He has also been running a grocery store where he sells many types of food. He make a good profit and intends to grow his business.

Amos is requesting a loan of 70,000 LRD to purchase more goods for his store. He hopes to purchase a taxi in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more goods for his store.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is 27 years old and married with no children. She has a business selling beans in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She has been in this business for three years. She earns additional income from selling alcohol.

Betty requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business. She will use the extra income for building a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more beans to sell.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a single lady with one child aged two years old whom she hopes to give a good education up to university level. She describes herself as faithful.

Esther sells onions. She has been doing so for three years, supplying them to local businesses in Mombasa. She says that while the business is profitable, financial constraints are her major challenge.

Esther is using her loan of 20,000 KES to buy more onions to boost her business and so meet the demands of her customers. In the future she hopes to continue to sell more onions than at present and purchase a pickup to help her in the business.

loans.use: to buy more onions to sell.

loans.name: Shaban

texts.en:
Shaban is a twenty-nine-year-old married man with four children. He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. Shaban is solely charged with the responsibility of looking after his family, and his dream is to set up an income-generating activity to support them.

Shaban has been operating a grocery for four years amidst the hardships imposed by inflation. He needs a loan of 2,200,000 UGX to buy sugar, cassava flour and soap to sell. His vision is to have a wholesale business plus a better residential home.

loans.use: to buy sugar, cassava flour and soap to sell.

loans.name: Shem

texts.en: Shem is a thirty-year-old married man with two children. He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the produce business for one and a half years and he started the business with capital acquired from farming. Some of the hardships he faces are poor means of communication, and theft, but nonetheless his vision is to own a food store that can ably supply the western region of the country, and to have an educated family. Shem needs this loan to buy beans for resale.

loans.use: to buy beans for resale.

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en:
Joshua has been in farming for 15 years in his native home in Kisii, South Rift, Kenya. He is married, with eight children, five of whom are of school-going age. His farm produces onions, tomatoes, cabbages, beans, and tea, all sold within the local market.

Joshua has requested a loan of 80,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy a dairy cow for 50,000 KES and construct a dairy unit for 30,000 KES. He says the loan will help him pay for his children's education as well as improve his profit through economies of scale.

Joshua appreciates the work of Juhudi Kilimo in helping small farmers do business. He sees poor road networks as the challenge in farming.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow and construct a dairy unit.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
This is 31-year-old Mohamed. He is married and has two children, aged 11 and 8 years; they are in school. He has two dependents who live with him because they are in school. 

In 2004, Mohamed established his used shoe business. He began his business because he saw it to be lucrative and a way to actualize his dream of independence. Working seven days a week and 11 hours a day, he earns about 1,200,000 Sierra Leone leone (LE) every month from this business. 

Mohamed requires a loan in order to buy more used shoes. He would like a loan in the amount of 3,000,000 LE. In the future, Mohamed plans to establish a larger shop and to become a supplier. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more used shoes.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles is an honest 51-year-old business man. He is married, and blessed with four children of whom two are in school. For the last 15 years he has been running a chemist's shop to make ends meet. In the next five years he wants to become a major distributor of medicine. He is requesting a loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings to buy medicine for his shop. Thanks to Faulu Kenya he has been able to learn business management skills.

loans.use: to buy more medicines.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to add to his stock.

loans.name: Kamughobe Tukolerehaghuma Group

texts.en: Benedicto is a 43-year-old married man with seven children. He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. The responsibility of looking after the family rests on him and his aspiration is to see all his children graduate from university. He has been operating a retail shop for three years. He started the shop with 250,000 shillings and now has 1,800,000 shillings as his working capital. He is a member of a group where each member guarantees the other to obtain a loan. His vision is to someday own a wholesale shop. Benedicto needs this loan to buy saucepans, salt, and jerrycans for resale.

loans.use: to buy saucepans, salt, and jerrycans.

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a 32-year-old married man with three children. He rents a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been running a butchery for seven years, and this has facilitated him in catering to his family's needs. His hardships are theft and price fluctuations, and his vision is owning a ranch, plus educating the children. Hussein intends to use the credit to buy cows to sell.

loans.use: To buy cows to sell.

loans.name: Kerima

texts.en:
Kerima is 49 years old. She is a widow with five children, all of whom are in school. She has a business selling soft drinks in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She has been running this business for two years.

Kerima requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business. She will use the profit from this loan to build a new house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase soft drinks like mango juice and lemon juice to sell

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 46 years old. He is married, with five children. He has been farming on his piece of land for the past fifteen years, and sells the farm produce to his customers in Narok Town.

He has applied for his second loan from KADET LTD to purchase farm supplies such as seeds and fertilizer, and to buy more animals. He has been a good client. He hopes to make a profit and use it to educate his children and expand his farm.

He hopes to make profit and use it to re-invest in another business. He is a persevering man who can do more if funded.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a resident and a farmer in Kisii, South Rift, Kenya, where he lives with his family of five children aged between 12 and below 2 years. Joseph runs a hotel in the local market. His farm produces maize, milk, beans and potatoes.

Joseph has made a request for a loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow and construct a dairy unit. He says the income will enable him to educate his children and further expand his farming business. He wants to run a wholesale shop in the local market.

Joseph is concerned with the high running costs of animal diseases and poor infrastructure.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow and construct a dairy unit.

loans.name: Jariatu

texts.en:
This is 42-year-old Jariatu. She is married and has 4 children aged 17, 15, 11 and 2. She has 1 additional dependent who lives with her - her younger brother.  In 2001, Jariatu established her cotton material business. She started her business because she had gained experience from her husband. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about Le 1,000,000 every month. She would like a loan of Le 5,000,000. Jariatu has already received and successfully repaid 3 loans. She now requires a new loan to buy additional lace and dry cotton. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 250,000. In the future, Jariatu plans to educate her children, extend her business and to get a permanent house. 
She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To pay for material for her business

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is 38 years old. She is married and has four children. She is a fruit vendor. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years with a monthly income of KES.4,000. 

She is applying for her first loan with which she plans to buy more stock. She hopes to grow her business and to improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: to buy more stock of fruit

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is a forty-two-year old married mother of five children. She owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. The responsibility of looking after the family is vested in her as her husband does not work. She has been selling clothes for ten years. She started with 50,000 shillings and now has 3,000,000 shillings as her working capital. Her major hardship is the seasonal nature of the business. Her vision is to have a big boutique plus to educate her children. Jane needs the money to buy clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is a hardworking and determined 34-year-old business man. He is married and blessed with two school going children aged 5 and 3. He has been operating a beauty salon for the past 4 years. He supplements income from this venture with the salary he earns from his job. He wants, in the next 5 years, to have expanded his business and opened up several other beauty salons. His dream is to be self employed. He is requesting a loan of 55000 Kenya shillings to buy a dryer. Thanks to Faulu Kenya he is now financially literate.

loans.use: to buy a dryer

loans.name: Sanare

texts.en:
Sanare, 40 years old, is married with four children. He has been in mixed farming for the past nine years.
He was introduced to KADET LTD  by a registered client in his abode. 

This is his second loan with which he plans to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers, seeds and chemicals. He intends to use the return from the loan to plough back into his farming and to repay the loan.

His dreams are to become a famous farmer in the area and to educate his children to a higher level of education. He is an industrious man who will try  hard to achieve if funded.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Claudio

texts.en: Claudio is 36 years old, and married with eight children aged 2-11 years. He is the sole bread winner for his family of 10 people living in Hoima, Uganda. For two years, he has been operating a general merchandise shop. From this business, he has been able to buy a vehicle; however, his only challenge is the high inflation rate. He hopes in the future to upgrade his shop to a wholesale status. Claudio needs a loan to buy sugar, soap, and salt to sell.

loans.use: To buy soap, sugar, and salt to sell.

loans.name: Calleb

texts.en:
Calleb is 39 years old, and married to Selestine.  They have four children.

Calleb has had a welding business for the past three years, and is applying for his third loan from KADET LTD to enable him buy more steel for making steel doors.

He hopes to have a big welding firm in the future.

loans.use: To buy steel for making steel doors.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy crates of soda for resale.

loans.name: Alhaji Mohamed

texts.en: This is 34-year-old Mohamed.  He is married, and has three children aged 7, 10, and 13. In 1989, Mohamed established his used clothing business. He began this business because he gained the experience of selling used clothing from his late father. Used clothes are easy to sell. Working seven days-a- week, and ten hours a day, he earns about Le 1,200,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of Le 5,000,000. Mohamed has already received, and successfully repaid three loans. He now requires a new loan in order to buy additional mini dresses, tan tops, and cotton shirts. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 300,000. In the future, Mohamed plans to educate his children, and finish his building. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To pay for additional used clothing.

loans.name: Bujubuli Abeteraine Development Association Group

texts.en:
Robert is a Ugandan male, aged 31 years. He needs a loan to buy land. He hails from Kyenjojo District, and is a father of one child aged two years. He is a retailer, who dreams of becoming a whole-seller and educating his child. 
He is a member of Bujubuli Abeteraine Development Group, the group is comprised of fifteen people, but two did not take the loan, and they are in the photo because the policy requires them to guarantee their members while accessing credit facilities.

loans.use: To buy land.

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson is a mason and a farmer in Kisii town, South Rift, Kenya. He has been in farming for 15 years with his farm producing maize, tea, tomatoes and vegetables. He is married with 10 children, with 8 still in school

Samson has requested a loan of 60,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a water tank and a dairy cow. He says the business will educate his children. He is also planning to purchase more land to facilitate expansion.

He points at animal diseases and poor markets as the challenges in farming.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow and a water tank

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is 27 years old and married with four children, two of whom are in school. She has a business selling bread in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She has been running this business for three years.

Flora requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her to pay for her children to go to school.

loans.use: to purchase more bread to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more bags of coffee and bananas to resell

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 26 years old, married, and has two children aged five years old and three years old. He runs a battery charging business at Kinanie market in Kitengela and is known by the name Neema Battery Charging. He has been running this business for eight months and has provided employment to one person. Daniel plans to use his loan to buy a welding machine to grow his business through diversifying to welding. 

Daniel hopes to grow his business to become a market leader in battery charging in Kitengela. He describes himself as determined.

loans.use: to buy a welding mchine

loans.name: Santina

texts.en:
Santina is 36 years old and married with one child who is in is school. She has a business selling tomatoes, onions and cooking oil in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She has been in this business for three years.

Santina requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business.

loans.use: to purchase more onions and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy shoes to sell

loans.name: Idriss

texts.en:
This is 34-year-old Idriss.  He is married and has 2 children aged 2 and 1. He has one additional dependent who lives with him because she is his stepdaughter.

In 1995, Idriss established his school uniform and tailoring materials business. He began his business because he gained the experience of material sales through his elder brother and because uniform sales gives more profit. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about 1,100,000 SLL every month from this business.

He would like a loan in the amount of 5,000,000 SLL. Idriss has already received and successfully repaid 2 loans and now requires a new loan in order to buy additional schooling materials. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 250,000 SLL. In the future, Idriss plans to get a dwelling house and educate his children.  He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to pay for additional used clothing for his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to obtain more plastic containers to resell.

loans.name: Kibaya Tutungukye Group B

texts.en:
Milton, a father of five, operates a cattle sales business in Kihihi, located in the western part of Uganda. Having established his enterprise with savings from his farming enterprise, which he still operates, this strongly motivated and ambitious man has seen his business make significant headway during this last decade despite financial difficulties in the procurement of additional cattle to resell. Milton's diligence, cooperation with close friends and family and a strong determination have contributed to his progress.

Milton exudes confidence and he invariably creates a relaxed and placid atmosphere around those he deals with. He reckons that he will be able to bask in the glow of increased profits when he gets this loan, which he will use to purchase more cattle for resale. By his own account, he is good credit risk, and estimates his gross monthly sales to be Uganda shillings 250,000. This will be the second group loan for Milton's group.

loans.use: to purchase more cattle to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase various provisions to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy palm fruits to process into oil to sell.

loans.name: Armando Jose

texts.es: Armando José posee una moto taxi la cual brinda el servicio de transporte en las zonas alejadas de la ciudad, Armando arquila la moto taxi para que otro señor trabaje y le entregue lo que gana pues él trabaja como maestro de primaria. Armando tuvo que ahorrar para comprarse so moto taxi y poder proporcionarle a su familia más ingresos. El crédito es para la compra de llantas, focos, frenos, y pintar la moto taxi.
texts.en: Armando José has a moto taxi which offers a transport service to the remote zones of the city. Armando rents out the moto taxi so that another person can work and give him what he earns, as Armando works as an elementary school teacher. Armando had to save up to buy himself the moto taxi in order to offer his family more income. This loan is for the purchase of tires, headlights, brakes, and to paint the moto taxi.

loans.use: to purchase tires, headlights, brakes, and to paint the moto taxi.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to acquire extra palm fruits to process to make more sales.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena is divorced and has two children. She fries fish to sell in Abura, which she has been doing for 10 years. As a divorcee, single-handedly taking care of her children has not been easy. A loan will go a long way to help her buy more fresh fish to fry for sale. She plans to reinvest the new profits from her expanded business for further growth and to take care of the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy more fresh fish to fry for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to get a bigger varieties of slippers, so she can meet the demands of her customers.

loans.name: Virgen De La O Group

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “VIRGEN D. LA O”; el banco se encuentra ubicado en el Distrito D. Yucay, en la Provincia D. Urubamba y Departamento D. Cusco.

La socia es la señora Higidia; la socia es casada y tiene 57 años D. edad, la socia tiene 6 hijos; la socia trabaja en la agricultura y comercio minorista; la socia tiene un terreno en el cual produce maíz D. exportación, generalmente ella cuenta con sus clientes a los que directamente les venD. toda la producción D. maíz blanco D. primera, son granos grandes y dulces, la socia trabaja su terreno situado en Tarabamba, la socia tiene dos D. sus hijos independientes y los otros 4 aún dependen D. ella, la socia suele invertir la ganancia D. sus producto en los estudios D. sus hijos, en la compra D. víveres para el hogar y otros, la socia requiere el crédito para invertir en la compra D. semillas, abonos y el tractor que removerá la tierra para prepara la nueva siembra D. maíz. La socia solicita comprar semillas, pagara el tractor que preparara la tierra y comprar el abono para la nueva siembra D. maíz blanco.
La fotografia adjuntada  ala foto grupal pertenece a la socia Hortencia y se anexo al grupo poruqe ella tenía permiso D. llegar tarD. y al momento en el que ella se hizo precente ya 5 socios se habian retirado del grupo.


Los otros socios se dedican a la agricultura, venta D. maíz y productos secos, a la crianza D. animales menores, a la docencia.

La socia agradece el apoyo que se le otorgara y así mismo se compromete a cumplir D. manera disciplinada con los pagos D. las cuotas.
texts.en:
The member belongs to the Virgen D. La O communal bank; the bank is located in the Yucay district, Urubamba province, Cusco department.

The member is Mrs. Higidia; she is 57 and married. She has 6 children. She works in agriculture and retail. She has a plot of land on which she produces corn for export. She generally has clients to whom she directly sells all of her white corn crop. White corn is a large, sweet grain. She works her land, which is located in Tarabamba. Two of her children are independent and the other 4 still depend on her. She usually invests her income from her crops in her children's studies, in the purchase of household supplies, and other items. She needs this loan to invest in the purchase of seeds, fertilizers and a tractor which will till the land to prepare for the new corn crop. She is requesting to purchase seeds, to pay for the tractor that prepares the land, and to purchase the fertilizer for the new crop of white corn.

The other members work in agriculture; sell corn and dry products; raise small animals; and teach.

The member is grateful for the support provided and also promises to be disciplined with the repayments of the quotas.

The small photograph is of Hortencia, who had permission to arrive late to the group meeting. At the moment that she came the other 5 members had already left.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, pay for the tractor that prepares the land, and purchase the fertilizer for the new crop of white corn.

loans.name: Cesar Augusto

texts.es: Cesar Augusto tiene su negocio que es la venta de productos plásticos. Hace más de dos años, inicio por la necesidad de no poder trabajar en su profesión, uno de sus mayores desafíos obtener ventas diariamente  ya que algunas veces no obtienes muchas ganancias, por lo que cesar tiene que andar bajo sol buscando a sus clientes. El sueño de cesar es poder tener un local en donde pueda recibir mejor a sus clientes. El préstamo es para la compra de bolsa, platos desechables, cucharas, vasos.
texts.en: Cesar Augusto has had a business selling plastic products for over two years. He started it out of need, as he was unable to work in his profession. One of his greatest challenges is obtaining daily sales since sometimes he does not make much money. For this reason he has to walk around under the sun in search of customers. His dream is to be able to have a store where he can better receive his customers. This loan is for the purchase of bags, disposable plates, spoons, cups.

loans.use: to purchase bags, disposable plates, spoons, cups

loans.name: Marvin Adrian

texts.es: Marvin Adrián tiene 31 años, su negocio es la venta y elaboración de tortillas, tiene más de dos años en esta actividad por lo que anteriormente quedo desempleado y no tenía la forma de mantener a su familia, la lucha constante que realiza en esta actividad ha hecho de Marvin un futuro empresario el financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de maíz, cal, leña, bolsas plásticas entre otros. Uno de sus sueños es terminar de construir su casa.
texts.en: Marvin Adrián is 31. His business is making and selling tortillas. He has done this for over two years, as before he was unemployed and had no way of supporting his family. This work is a constant struggle and is making him into a businessman. This loan is for the purchase of corn, lime, firewood, plastic bags, and other items. One of his dreams is to finish building his home.

loans.use: to purchase corn, lime, firewood, plastic bags, and other items.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase 10 drums of red oil for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to procure more plastic containers to re-sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase basic grains, candies, detergent, drinks, toilet paper, canned goods and soups.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to obtain food items to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To procure more millet and other ingredients to make porridge for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase 150 bags of charcoal for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fresh corn to roast for sale.

loans.name: Binh

texts.en:
Binh is a 42-year-old married woman living in Ho Chi Minh City. She lives with her husband, one son and one daughter. She has operated a food stall for five years in her local community. Her husband also helps her to sell noodles.

Binh would like a loan to purchase new furniture and a greater quality and quantity of food to sell from her stall. She hopes this will enable her to better meet the needs of her customers and attract additional customers. 

She also hopes that through the loan she will be able to increase her income and save money for any future difficulties facing her family.

loans.use: to purchase new furniture and food for sale.

loans.name: Martha Veronica

texts.es: La señora Martha verónica se dedica a la venta de cosméticos y mercaderia en general el negocio inicio con ayuda de su mama que también se dedica al negocio, pues ella desde pequeña aprendió esta actividad ya que con el paso del tiempo Martha aprendió este negocio y ahora tiene su propio negocio. Martha tiene un de quince años bajo su cargo que tiene que proporcionarle. Alimento, estudio y vestimenta. Solicita el crédito para la compra de lápiz labial, pintura e uña, cremas, perfumes y ropa interior.
texts.en: Mrs Martha Verónica sells cosmetics and general merchandise. She started this business with the help of her mother, who also works in the business. This meant that Martha learned this business at a young age as time passed. She now has her own business. Martha has a 15-year-old child under her care for whom she must provide food, clothing and an education. She is requesting this loan for the purchase of lip liner, nail polish, creams, perfumes, and underwear.

loans.use: to purchase lip liner, nail polish, creams, perfume, and underwear.

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine lives in Uganda. She is single and has two children who are in school. She also takes care of  her mother. 

Justine lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include electricity, rent and school fees.   

Justine has a business of a restaurant. She has been in this business for two years, and she works seven days out of every week.  

Justine has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas, beef, chicken and a bag of rice. 

The main business challenges for Justine include defaulters and rainy season. Her goal for her business is to own a fully stocked restaurant and she also hopes to build her own house.

loans.use: To buy more beef, chicken, bunches of bananas and a bag of rice.

loans.name: Binh

texts.en:
Binh is a 31-year-old married man living with his wife and daughter in Ho C. Minh city.

Binh’s has been running a coffee shop for three years. He plans to use this loan to buy more furniture to renovate his shop and buy more coffee and beverages for selling.

Binh hopes that through the loan he will be able to generate additional income to reinvest in his shop and adequately cover his family's living expenses.

loans.use: to buy more furniture to renovate his shop and buy more coffee and beverages for selling.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase two barrels of used clothes for her business.

loans.name: Ana Luisa

texts.es: La Sra. Ana es casada, tiene 3 hijos todos en edad escolar; ella se dedica a la venta de comida en su casa, la Sra. Ana es muy emprendedora quiere crecer aun mas con su negocio; el crédito solicitado lo va a utilizar en la compra de un carrito sanguchero, accesorios y mesas para su nuevo negocio el cual va a ser la venta de sanguches, salchipapas y salchipollos y va a funcionar todas las noches, es un re préstamo Kiva. La Sra. Ana tiene el sueño de tener un gran restaurante en su casa. Ella está muy agradecida por el crédito otorgado.
texts.en: Mrs. Ana is married. She has three school-aged children and sells food in her home. Mrs. Ana is very enterprising and wants her business to grow even more. She will use the requested loan in the purchase of a food cart, accessories and tables for her new business which will be selling sandwiches, salchipapas [fried potatoes with hot dog], and salchipollo [fried potatoes with chicken]. She will run this business every night. This is a Kiva loan. Mrs. Ana dreams of having a large restaurant in her home. She is very grateful for the authorized loan.

loans.use: to purchase a food cart and tables for her new business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase four cartons of frozen fish for her business.

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.es: Ana Maria tiene 37 años, su actividad es la venta de comida desde hace mas de 1 año que se dedica a este medio de vida, aunque no es fácil obtener a sus clientes contentos el esfuerzo que diariamente realiza Ana es muy admirable. Inicio este medio de vida por la necesidad de apoyar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar juntos tienen 2 hijos a su cargo. Es por este motivo que realiza este financiamiento para la compra de materia prima como arroz, frijoles, aceite, bolsas, platos desechables entre otros.
texts.en: Ana Maria is 37. She has sold food for over a year. Even though it is not  easy to keep her customers happy she makes an admirable effort every day. She started this business out of the necessity to help her husband with the household costs. Together they have two children to care for. For this reason, she is taking out a loan for the purchase of staples such as rice, beans, oil, bags, disposable plates, and other items.

loans.use: to purchase corn, beans, oil, bags, disposable plates and other items.

loans.name: Chinh

texts.en: Chinh is a 59-year-old widower living in Ho Chi Minh city. He has 4 children. Chinh earns an income to support his children by running a business that specializes in laminating papers and objects with plastic. Chinh has been in the plastic lamination business for 7 years. He plans to use this loan to buy more plastic and other materials to expand his business by offering a greater range of lamination services and increasing the capacity of his business. Chinh hopes that through this loan he will be able to increase his income and better support his children.

loans.use: to buy more plastic and other materials

loans.name: Tereza

texts.en:
Tereza lives in Uganda. She is single and has 7 children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (her in-laws). Tereza has a business selling charcoal. She has been in this business for 2 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Tereza sells her products from home. She has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva's partner, MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. 

She also generates additional income through renting rooms and selling piped water. The main business challenges for Tereza include increasing prices of charcoal and the rainy season. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to be a wholesaler and also to start selling charcoal to the villages of Luwero. Tereza lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but not piped water. Her major monthly expenses include paying for electricity, rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy rice for selling.

loans.name: Suma Chuyma Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “SUMA CHUYMA” iniciará su primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Santiago II, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva encabezada por la señora Nola. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: repostería, promotora de venta, cosméticos, ventas de colchas y prendas de vestir, comercio de prendas de segunda mano.

La señora Nola,indica que este es el primer año que trabaja con Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de amigas para formar un grupo. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio punto ENTEL e Internet, que viene trabajando de dos años, por intermedio de sus hermanos.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para aumentar su capital (compra de cabinas de telefono), que compraran de la Huyustus y de la 16 de julio y posteriormente  lo incorporará en su tienda. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia, pues ella es casada y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta la capacitación.
texts.en:
The “SUMA CHUYMA” communal bank is starting its first cycle in Pro Mujer as part of the Santiago II Center. The group has 8 members and is directed by a board of directors headed by Mrs. Nola. The members' businesses are varied and include: a bakery; a sales representative; cosmetics; selling bedspreads and clothing; and selling second-hand clothing.

Mrs. Nola says that this is her first year working with Pro Mujer. She joined when friends invited her to form the group. She currently has an Entel store and an internet shop. She has done this for two years with her brothers' help.

The loan that she will now take out is to increase her working capital (purchasing phone booths), which she will purchase from the Huyustus and 16 de Julio [markets] and add to her store. This work allows her to generate an income to support her family where possible. She is married and has two children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she responds that she likes the training.

loans.use: to purchase telephone booths.

loans.name: Epina Luz

texts.es: La Sra. Epina tiene 33 años de edad, es madre soltera tiene 2 hijos, uno de ellos en edad escolar, ella se dedica a la venta de alfalfa ya tiene 3 años en el negocio, se dedico a este negocio viendo a su madre que también se dedicaba a lo mismo y tenia buena rentabilidad, el crédito otorgado lo va a invertir en la compra de abarrotes ya que desea poner una tienda en su casa (ya cuenta con andamios y vitrinas); su principal sueño de la Sra. Epina es construir su casa y darle una mejor calidad de vida a sus hijos.
texts.en: Mrs. Epina is 33. She is a single mother of 2 children, one of whom is school-aged. She has sold alfalfa for 3 years. She started this business because her mother also sells alfalfa and Epina saw that this was profitable. She will invest this loan in the purchase of groceries, because she wants to open a store in her home (she already has counters and display cases). Epina's main dream is to build a home and provide her children with a better quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase groceries in order to open a store.

loans.name: Rwabigangura Bakyara Twimukye Group

texts.en:
Business ownership from 34-year-old Juliet's estimation is a proposition that is well worthwhile from many angles. First, owning a business means one is their own boss, so they can make their own decisions. Secondly, one has many opportunities to learn and open new horizons for their business. Third, the diligence and long hours one employs in that business directly benefit the entrepreneur.

Before this happy mother of 6 set forth in her food sales business 20 years ago, she took the time upfront to explore and evaluate her prospective business and goals. Then she drew up a well thought out and comprehensive business plan to ensure she reaches her goals. Her pro-activeness, perseverance and resolve have come in handy in helping her notch up many successes.

Juliet sells high flavor foods and crops such as coffee, beans, ground nuts, maize, etc. at one of the biggest food markets in Rukungiri. Before she took root in this business, she worked in housekeeping. On the side, she has a modest retail outlet. She says the gross sales income from this business totals 250,000 Uganda shillings a month.

This is the third loan cycle for Juliet's borrowing group. Juliet says she intends to use this Kiva loan to purchase more foods such as bananas, beans, and groundnuts to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more foods such as bananas, beans, and groundnuts to resell

loans.name: Marina Antonia

texts.es: La señora Marina es cliente de nuestra institución, uno de sus mayores desafíos recientemente es el precio de sus productos, ya que están cada día más caros. Tiene tres hijos, pero ellos trabajan de manera independiente, ella siempre ha trabajado para proporcionarle los ingresos necesarios. Su actividad es la venta de nacatamales y cosa de horno, gracias a su actividad ella con su familia están saliendo adelante el préstamo que están solicitando es para la compra de hojas, masa, cerdo bolsas entre otros productos.
texts.en: Sra. Marina is one of our customers.  A recent challenge is the cost of the supplies she needs for her business, supplies that are becoming more expensive by the day.  She has three children, all grown and independent.  She has always worked to earn what she needs to live.  Sra. Marina operates a prepared foods business, making and selling nacatamales and other oven-prepared foods.  Thanks to the business, she and her family can support themselves.  She will use this loan to buy dough, pork, bags and other supplies she needs for the business.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her prepared foods business.

loans.name: Suma Pancara Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “SUMA PANCARA” iniciará su primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Cascada, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva encabezada por la señora Elena. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: venta de lana de alpaca, venta de fruta, venta de pan, venta de peluches, costura de deportivos, costura de pantalones.

La señora Elena,  indica que esta es la primera ves que trabaja con Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio venta de hilado de vicuña, que viene trabajando hace cuatro años.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para aumentar su capital (compra de lana de vicuña), que comprara de la 16 de julio y posteriormente  elaborado su producto lo venderá en las ferias. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia, pues ella es casada y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el credito.
texts.en:
The SUMA PANCARA community bank is starting on its first round of funding from Pro Mujer as part of the Centro Cascada.  The group has eight members and is managed by a board lead by Sra. Elena.  The members operate businesses such as: alpaca wool sales, fruit sales, bread sales, toy sales and sewing services.  

Sra. Elena, who says this is the first time that she has worked with Pro Mujer, was invited to join the group.  She has operated a business selling vicuna thread for four years.
 
Sra. Elena will use this loan to increase her working capital (for buying vicuna wool).  She will buy the wool in 16 de Julio, turn it into thread and sell it at local markets.  The business generates an income that helps to support her family.  She is married and has two children.

When we asked her what she likes about Pro Mujer, she answered that she likes the loans.

loans.use: to buy wool for her crafts business.

loans.name: Wilfredo

texts.es: El Sr. Wilfredo es casado, vive con su esposa y sus hijos, él es  un hombre lleno de aspiraciones y muy trabajador, se dedica al servicio de transporte urbano como taxista y/o colectivo, lleva trabajando así por más de 5 años, el Sr. Wilfredo quiere tener una mejor calidad de vida es por ello  que el crédito lo va a utilizar en la compra de accesorios para el motor de su auto y darle un mantenimiento en general, para que así el vehículo no sufra ningún desperfecto y pueda seguir laborando en el, tiene un sueño el cual es tener más adelante una casa bonita, grande para él y su familia. El Sr. Wilfredo está muy agradecido por el crédito otorgado.
texts.en: Sr. Wilfredo lives with his wife and children.  He is an ambitious man and very hard-working.  He operates a taxi business, his livelihood for more than 5 years now.  Sr. Wilfredo wants a better quality of life so he has to keep his vehicle in good order.   That's why he is applying for a loan to buy car parts and pay for general vehicle maintenance.  The vehicle has to be in good shape so that he can continue to work.  For the future, he would like to have a nicer house, one big enough for him and his family.  Sr. Wilfredo is very grateful for this loan.

loans.use: to pay for maintenance and buy parts for his taxi business.

loans.name: Denis Roberto

texts.es: Denis Roberto tiene 27 años, su actividad es la venta de medicamentos. Hace más de 8 años que tiene este negocio, Denis trabaja por cuenta propia pues es muy difícil encontrar un trabajo que le genere ganancias. El objetivo del financiamiento es para la compra de vitaminas, inyecciones, pastillas, pomadas entre otros productos. A pesar de los desafíos que enfrenta diariamente como es exponerse a que le roben el medicamento y lo que ha recolectado en el día.
texts.en: Denis Roberto, 27, has operated a herbal medicines business for more than 8 years.  He started the business because it is very difficult to find work that pays enough to live.  He will use this loan to buy vitamins, injections, pills, pomades and other products that he will sell.  Among the challenges he faces are those who rob him of his merchandise and daily earnings.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for his retail business.

loans.name: Mercedes Celina

texts.es:
La señora Mercedes tiene más de cinco años de manejar el negocio de pulpería, se ha dedicado a atender su negocio después de la muerte de su mama, Mercedes estudia en la universidad por las noches.
En su negocio de pulpería vende granos básicos como ser maíz, azúcar, frijoles, arroz, pollo, queso, mantequilla, artículos de limpieza, shampoo, jabón de baño y otros., sus clientes son los vecinos y amigos que le visitan a diario y  desea invertir el credito en la compra de abarrotaría y refrescos.
Su mayor deseo es terminar la universidad y remodelar su negocio a corto plazo.
texts.en:
Sra. Mercedes has owned a general store for more than five years.  She has run the store alone since her mother's death.  She studies at the local university in the evenings.   
Mercedes sells everyday products such as maize, sugar, beans, rice, chicken, cheese, butter, cleaning products, shampoo, bath soap, etc.  Her customers are her neighbors and friends.  She will use this loan to buy grocery products and soft drinks that she will resell.
Her greatest hopes are to remodel the store, as soon as possible, and to finish school.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her general store.

loans.name: Claudia Del Rosario

texts.es: Claudia Del Rosario es una mujer trabajadora que tiene un pequeño negocio que es la venta de refrescos. Comenzó hace 3 años con su negocio para mejorar la economía de su familia. Poco a poco fue incrementando su actividad. En la actualidad tiene una gran variedad de clientes que disfruta de sus deliciosos refrescos. Tiene muchas aspiraciones con su negocio por eso quiere seguir trabajando por lo que con el préstamo desea comprar bolsas, pajillas, frutas, entre otros.
texts.en: Claudia Del Rosario is a very hardworking woman who has a small business selling beverages.  She began her business three years ago in order to improve her family’s finances. Little by little she expanded and now has a large number of customers who enjoy her delicious drinks. She is very ambitious and wants to continue working. She wants to use the loan to buy containers, drinking straws and fruit among other things.

loans.use: to buy containers, drinking straws and fruit among other things.

loans.name: Gladys Argentina

texts.es:
La señora Gladys se  dedica a la elaboración de pan y quesadillas, con este negocio ha logrado sacar adelante a su familia, se esfuerza de lunes a sábado desde muy temprano para elaborar sus panes y quesadillas, luego prepara sus productos ya que tiene que salir a la ciudad a repartirlos, sus clientes son personas que visitan el mercado nuevo de San Lorenzo y los empleados de la empacadora de camarónes de esa zona.
Gladys tiene planes de invertir su préstamo en la compra de leña y maíz que son la materia prima para la elaboración de sus productos.

Su meta a corto plazo es terminar de arreglar su casa con las ganancias de las ventas de su negocio.
texts.en:
Gladys makes bread and quesadillas. With this business, she has been able to get her family ahead. She works Monday through Sunday starting very early to make her bread and quesadillas. Later she gets her products ready, since she goes out to the city to distribute them. Her customers are people who visit the new market of San Lorenzo and the employees of a shrimp packing plant in the area.  

Gladys has plans to invest her loan in buying firewood and corn, which are the raw materials to make her products.  

Her short term goal is to fix up her house with the earnings from her sales.

loans.use: to buy firewood and corn.

loans.name: Amigas De Fe Y Alegria Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “AMIGAS DE FE Y ALEGRIA” iniciará el ciclo número cuatro en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Germán Busch.  Está compuesta por ocho integrantes, la asociación comunal está dirigida por una mesa directiva a la cabeza de la señora  Ilaria.   Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: venta de pescado, brosteria, venta de panza, venta de poleras, producción de colchones.
 
La señora Ilaria indica que es el tercer ciclo que integra una asociación comunal en Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una promotora. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de brosteria, que viene trabajando hace una año atrás.

El crédito que sacará ahora es para el aumento de capital (compra de carne de gallina) los que compra de la distribuidora y lo venderá en su tienda. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia, pues ella vive en unión libre y tiene tres hijos.
texts.en:
The “AMIGAS DE FE Y ALEGRIA” [Friends of Faith and Happiness] community association will begin its fourth cycle in Pro Mujer, as a part of the Germán Busch center. It is made up of eight members. The community association is led by a board of directors and the head is Ilaria. The community association members' businesses are varied. Among them, we have: selling fish, roasted chicken, tripe, t-shirts, and making mattresses.  
 
Ilaria indicates that this is the third cycle that she has been a member of the community association in Pro Mujer. She joined at the invitation of a developer. At present she has a business selling roasted chicken, which she has done for a year.  

The loan that she will take out now is to increase her capital to buy chicken. She will buy it at a distributor and sell it at her store. This work allows her to generate income to support her family as much as possible. She is in a common law marriage with three children.

loans.use: to buy chicken

loans.name: Heroes Del Chaco Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “HEROES DEL CHACO” iniciará su primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del centro focal Panamericana, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva encabezada por la señora Francisca. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: Inicio de negocio de ganado, trenzado de mantas, ayudante de albañil, costura de chamarras, peluquería, venta de tostados.

La señora Francisca,  indica que es la primera ves que trabaja en Pro Mujer y que integro la institución por invitación de una promotora en la zona. En la actualidad ella pretende iniciar un negocio de crianza de ganado (compra de ganado) que adquirirá de la Ceja  y posteriormente lo venderá en su pueblo. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia, pues ella es casada y tiene ocho hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el credito.
texts.en:
The “Heroes del Chaco” (Heroes of the Chaco Region) communal bank has launched its 1st loan cycle with Pro Mujer (Pro-Woman), as part of the Panamericana office. The group consists of 8 members and is managed by a directing committee led by Francisca. The businesses the members practice are varied, including launching cattle-raising, weaving blankets, apprentice brick layer, sewing jackets, a barber shop, and selling deep-fried tortillas.

Francisca reports that this is the 1st time she has worked with Pro Mujer and that the group was initiated at the invitation of a promoter in the zone. At present, she is attempting to begin cattle-buying and raising. She purchases her livestock in La Ceja and later sells them in her village. This type of work permits her to generate resources to help her family. Francisca is married and has 8 children.

When asked what she likes best about Pro-Mujer, she responded that she likes the loan system.

loans.use: buy cattle to raise and sell.

loans.name: Samuel A.'s Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of a primary school in Jui, near Freetown. This group of teachers has come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek a loan of 5,500,000 SLL in order to buy or invest in something that their mere salaries cannot let them do. Some of them will use the loan to invest in a business, others will use it to pay school fees for their children, etc. 

Samuel is the leader of this group of teachers. The 48-year-old is married and has 4 children. Samuel was born in Bo city but now lives and works in Jui. Samuel has requested this loan for developmental purposes. He will use it to buy pieces of furniture and pay his children’s school fees.

loans.use: to buy pieces of furniture and pay his children’s school fees

loans.name: Flor Jacqueline

texts.es:
Flor tiene 45 años vive cerca de Ibarra con sus papas, no tiene hijos, se considera una persona organizada, preocupada por su comunidad, es cooperadora y muy responsable.

Trabaja pesando cerdos sola por un tiempo de 10 años, le va muy bien tiene clientela.

Trabaja por dos años con FODEMI, el crédito que solicita es para la compra de cerdos y así mejorar sus ingresos para poder arreglar su casa; su sueño es de llegar a tener una tercena (carnicería).

Flor en la foto se encuentra cosechando aguacates que también es su fuente de ingresos para mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Flor is 45, lives near Ibarra with her parents, and does not have children. She is considered an organized person who is concerned about her community. She is cooperative and very responsible.

She has been selling pork for 10 years. She has a clientele and has been doing well.

Flor has been working with FODEMI for two years. She is requesting a loan to buy pigs in order to increase her income so she can fix up her house. Her dream is to eventually have her own butcher shop. 

In the photo Flor is seen harvesting avocados which are also a source of income that helps to improve her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: to buy pigs

loans.name: Villa Anta Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “VILLA ANTA” iniciará su cuarto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del centro focal Los Andes, está compuesta por siete integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva encabezada por la señora Cristina. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: Tejido de alfombras, venta de comida, hilado de alpaca, venta de sombreros, tejido de gorros.

La señora Cristina, indica que es el segundo año que trabaja en Pro Mujer y que integro la institución por invitación de la promoción en zona. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de salteñas que viene trabajando hace siete años, cuando le enseño su esposo. 

El crédito que ahora sacará es para aumentar su capital (compra de harina) que adquirirá de la feria 16 de julio  y posterior a la elaboración lo comercializará en la misma feria los jueves y domingos. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia, pues ella esta casada y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta la recuperación del préstamo poco a poco.
texts.en:
The “Villa Anta” communal bank has begun its 4th loan cycle with Pro Mujer (Pro-Woman), as part of the Los Andes office. The group is composed of 7 members and is directed by a board headed by Cristina. The businesses the members promote are varied and include carpet weaving, selling meals, making thread from alpaca wool, selling hats, and knitting caps.

Cristina reports that this is her 2nd year working with Pro Mujer and that she entered the institution on the invitation of a promoter in the zone. She presently operates a business she began 7 years ago when her husband taught her how to bake and sell meat pies.

The loan she now seeks is to augment her capital, buying flour at the 16th of July Fair. Cristina will then bake and sell her products at the same fair on Thursdays and Sundays. This type of work enables her to generate resources to help her family. She is married and has 3 children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, Cristina responded that she likes recovering the borrowed money, little by little.

loans.use: buy flour to bake meat pies to sell.

loans.name: Los Andes 1 Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “LOS ANDES 1” iniciará su primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Senkata, está compuesta por siete integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva encabezada por la señora Teodora. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: comercio, producción y servicio.

La señora Teodora  indica que es la primera ves que trabaja con Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una promotora. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de tejido de mantas que viene trabajando hace años atrás por intermedio de sus amigas. 

El crédito que ahora sacará es para aumentar su capital (compra de lana) que comprará de la Ceja y posterior a la elaboración de sus productos los venderá a pedido. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia pues ella es casada y tiene cinco hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta capacitación.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Los Andes 1” is starting its first loan cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Senkata Community Center. The group consists of seven members and is led by a Board of Directors headed by Sra. Teodora. The members of the Communal Bank engage in different businesses in the retail, manufacturing, and service sectors in order to get ahead.

Sra. Teodora said that this is the first time she has worked with Pro Mujer. She was invited to join the organization by a promoter. Teodora currently has a business in which she knits blankets. Her friends convinced her to work several years ago.

The loan she is now receiving will be used to increase her capital for purchasing wool. She will buy the wool in the neighborhood of La Ceja and use it to make the products that she sells on request. Working in this manner allows her to generate income to support her family as much as possible. Teodora is married and has five children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, Teodora said that she enjoys the training seminars.

loans.use: to buy wool.

loans.name: Be Glad Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Rita is currently the group leader of the Be Glad Trust Bank Group made up of 9 members. She is a 26-year-old seamstress who is clearly active and hardworking. Rita sews for women and children according to the styles of her customers. She plans to use the requested loan to purchase sewing accessories to improve her products. Rita possesses 6 years of hands-on experience in sewing. 

Rita is married to a commercial driver and together they have one child who is 3 years old. She lives with her family in Takoradi, a coastal business hub of Ghana. Above all, she hopes to be financially able to support a building project to accommodate her family. As the leader of the group, Rita will ensure that all members attend meetings and submit their repayments.

loans.use: To purchase sewing accessories

loans.name: Oksana

texts.ru:
Оксана замужем. Ее супруга зовут Иван. У них двое взрослых детей. Проживают в селе Веселое.  Муж занимается сельским хозяйством, а  Оксана имеет свой собственный бизнес. 

Оксана владеет небольшим магазинчиком. Торгует она  бытовой химией, товарами для дома, одеждой, обувью, канцтоварами и игрушками. Конкурентов нет, так как  ее магазин единственный в селе. Люди не едут за сорок километров в город, что бы купить какую-нибудь мелочь для дома. И поэтому товар очень востребован. Оксана предприимчивая, трудолюбивая и прилежная. Имеет хорошую репутацию и дружеские отношения с клиентами. Ее бизнес является основным доходом семьи.

Оксана просит предоставить ей кредит в сумме 20,000 гривен на закупку посуды, игрушек и одежды.
texts.en:
Oksana lives in the village of Veseloye. She's married to Ivan and they have two children. 
Ivan is a farmer, while Oksana runs a small store. She sells household cleaning products, home goods, clothing, shoes, office supplies and toys. Her goods are in high demand. She owns the only store in the village, allowing customers to buy local and not travel 40 kilometers just to go shopping. Oksana doesn't lack initiative and is hard-working and diligent. She has a good reputation and great customer relations. Her business is the family's main source of income. 
Oksana's requesting a loan in order to purchase glassware, toys and clothing.

loans.use: to purchase glassware, toys and clothing

loans.name: Florecitas Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “FLORECITAS” iniciará su primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del centro focal Los Andes, está compuesta por nueve integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva encabezada por la señora Hilda. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: costura, tejido de guantes, venta de pollos, venta de verduras, macramé, tienda de abarrotes, peluquería, venta de guantes.

La señora Hilda, indica que es la primera ves que trabaja en Pro Mujer y que integro la institución por invitación de una amiga. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de carne que viene trabajando hace quince años atrás por el apoyo de sus padres. 

El crédito que ahora sacará es para  la compra de un refrigerador, para la refrigeración de la carne, este equipo lo comprará del matadero y lo acomodará en su tienda. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia, pues ella esta casada y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta los pagos quincenales, ya que se pagan mas rápidos.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Florecitas” (Little Flowers) is starting its first loan cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Los Andes Community Center. The group has nine members and is led by a Board of Directors headed by Sra. Hilda. The members engage in different business activities so that they can get ahead such as sewing, knitting gloves, selling chickens, selling vegetables, producing macramé, selling groceries, operating a beauty salon, and selling gloves.

Sra. Hilda says that this is the first time she has worked with Pro Mujer. She joined the organization after being invited by a friend. Hilda currently manages a business in which she sells meat. She started working in this business 15 years ago with the help of her parents.

The loan she is currently seeking will be used to buy a refrigerator for preserving meat. She will buy this piece of equipment from the slaughterhouse and set aside space for it in her shop. Working in this manner allows her to generate income to support her family. Hilda is married and has three children.
